item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Turkey’s President Criticizes Israel and Backs Hamas
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s comments are likely to strain relations between his government and those of other NATO members, including the United States.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa/Reuters
item.media:description: Searching for casualties at the site of Israeli strikes in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: From Gaza, an Audio Diary of Despair
item.description: In a series of voice memos sent via WhatsApp, Tasneem Ismael Ahel, 19, described the war unfolding around her in Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou

item.title: As Ukraine War Grinds On, Widows Try to See Life After Loss
item.description: Support groups formed to help thousands of new widows see a dual role in healing their nation. “Our society was not ready to face such scale of grief,” one widow said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Didukh hugging a photograph of her husband, Bohdan Didukh, at his funeral in Lviv in June.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Gaza Are Some of the Most Intense This Century
item.description: In the 19 days since Hamas attacked Israel, the Israeli military says it has struck more than 7,000 targets in Gaza. Palestinians accuse Israel of indiscriminately targeting civilians, but Israel officials say the strikes are aimed at eroding military infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gazans assess the damage from an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Food and Water Grow Scarce in Gaza Amid Israeli Siege and Strikes
item.description: Residents wait in line for hours for bread and water, with fights sometimes breaking out. The United Nations has called the situation a humanitarian catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Samar Abu Elouf
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting with jugs to fill up at one of the few water stations still functioning in the southern town of Khan Younis on Tuesday.

item.title: Shoplifting Surges in U.K., and Workers Face Scary Situations
item.description: As people try to walk away with goods, it’s “like the Wild West,” says one store owner, whose employees have been hit and bitten on the job.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Inglis, the owner of three Welcome grocery stores in Southampton, England, checking security camera footage at one of his shops.

item.title: As Bombs Fall in Gaza, History Hangs Over a Family Fighting to Survive
item.description: From his Los Angeles home, Mohammed Abujayyab has sought to help his grandmother and other relatives survive the Israeli bombardment. Memories of displacement are never far.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians on Monday buying vegetables in the Nuseirat Market in the central Gaza Strip. The market had been bombed by Israeli warplanes earlier in the war.

item.title: Ex-Fashion Executive, Peter Nygard, Testifies in His Sexual Assault Trial
item.description: A lawyer for Peter Nygard, a former fashion executive accused of sexually assaulting five women, described their testimony as “revisionist history.’’
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Cole Burston/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter Nygard arriving at court in Toronto in September.

item.title: Gavin Newsom, on Climate Mission to China, Meets With Xi Jinping
item.description: The California governor is on a weeklong visit to China aimed at negotiating climate partnerships.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Office of the Governor of California, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, left, met with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. This photograph was released by the governor’s office.

item.title: A Hindu Mardi Gras Where Indian Progressivism Is Alive and Well
item.description: A huge religious carnival shows that India remains a country of diverse political and social beliefs, despite the right-wing national government’s dominance.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:description: The Durga Puja, the Bengal region’s biggest religious festival, concluded in Kolkata on Tuesday.

item.title: Transgender Ruling Is Step Forward for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights in Japan
item.description: The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional a legal clause requiring transgender people to undergo sterilization to legally change their gender identity.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Yuichi Yamazaki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A rally during the International Transgender Day of Visibility in Tokyo in March.

item.title: Women Will Vote at a Vatican Meeting for the First Time
item.description: Some women participating in a conference on sensitive church issues said they feel heartened by the discussions taking place, though change may remain slow.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Although the Vatican policy gathering called the Synod on Synodality was still largely attended by men, women were allowed to participate for this first time this year.

item.title: Coming of Age During the War in Ukraine
item.description: Each age group has suffered through the war, but for young adults it has been particularly hard — and not just for those who have served on the frontline.
item.dc:creator: Laetitia Vancon and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: War does not wait for young love to bloom.

item.title: Migrants Who Follow U.S. Entry Rules Faces Endless Wait
item.description: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Cuauro at her home this month.

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Defends Hamas and Lashes Out at Israel
item.description: In a speech in Parliament, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused Israel of committing “massacres” in Gaza and said Hamas was fighting for “liberation.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Delay in Israel’s Gaza Ground Invasion to Bolster Air Defenses
item.description: The systems would allow the United States to provide more protection for American troops at bases in Iraq, Syria and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on Wednesday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he “won’t detail all the considerations we’re taking into account, most of them totally unknown to the public.”

item.title: Carnival Was Negligent in Covid Outbreak on Cruise Ship, Court Rules
item.description: An Australian judge found that the cruise company and a subsidiary “breached their duty of care” in handling a coronavirus outbreak on the Ruby Princess in March 2020.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Mark Metcalfe/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Ruby Princess cruise ship departing Port Kembla in Wollongong, Australia, in April 2020.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Gaza Is Running Out of Fuel
item.description: Plus Vietnam’s many cable cars.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A water filling station in the city of Khan Younis in Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: With Fuel Shortages in Gaza, U.N. Aid Group May Shut Down Operations
item.description: A U.N. agency that has offered a wartime lifeline to hundreds of thousands of Palestinians warned of “tough decisions” ahead if it cannot get fuel.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Gaza Strip, many filling stations, like this one in Khan Younis on Wednesday, have run out of fuel and closed.

item.title: Biden Reaffirms Support for Israel but Calls for Protection of Civilians
item.description: During an appearance with the Australian prime minister, President Biden pledged that the United States would provide Israel with what it needed to defend itself against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking during a joint press conference with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia.

item.title: Chasing Big Mergers, Oil Executives Dismiss Peak Oil Concerns
item.description: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are spending tens of billions of dollars buying oil and gas assets, betting that the International Energy Agency’s predictions of declining oil demand are wrong.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: ExxonMobil’s acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources creates a shale oil behemoth in the Permian Basin, the heart of the Texas and New Mexico oil patch.

item.title: Biden Seeks to Tame Oil Prices if Mideast Conflict Sends Them Soaring
item.description: The president has previously drawn down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to ease price pressures, but that could be more difficult now
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Oil tankers at one of the largest facilities in Russia. Russia has found ways around the price cap, forcing officials to take steps to crack down on enforcement of the cap in hopes of reducing the price at which Russian oil is sold.

item.title: What I Read and Watch to Decompress
item.description: Some Jane Austen and a tennis rom-com are just right the right relief when news of fighting and war takes a toll.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Cinematic, via Alamy
item.media:description: Kirsten Dunst as Lizzie Bradbury in the 2004 film “Wimbledon.”

item.title: Why Hurricane Otis Caught Many By Surprise
item.description: Storms don’t normally go from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in a day.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones
item.media:credit: CSU/CIRA & NOAA

item.title: Traveler Stranded in Acapulco Recounts ‘Apocalyptic’ Hurricane Otis
item.description: “It was really terrifying,” said one visitor who was attending a mining convention in the Mexican city.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Bush’s Institute Issues an Urgent Plea for Congress to Renew His AIDS Program
item.description: PEPFAR, created by President George W. Bush in 2003 to combat the disease, faces an uncertain future now that its authorizing legislation has lapsed.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: Although former President George W. Bush did not sign the letter urging Congress to renew his AIDS program, he has made no secret that he wants the program reauthorized.

item.title: A Close Look at Some Key Evidence in the Gaza Hospital Blast
item.description: A widely cited missile video does not shed light on what happened, a Times analysis concludes.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler, Haley Willis, Riley Mellen, Alexander Cardia, Natalie Reneau, Julian E. Barnes and Christoph Koettl

item.title: U.S. Cites ‘High Confidence’ Rocket From Gaza Caused Hospital Blast
item.description: American intelligence agencies released no new declassified imagery or other new evidence to make their case. Officials said their strengthened assessment was based on video evidence.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Abed Khaled/Associated Press
item.media:description: Wreckage at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City last week, a day after an explosion.

item.title: Israel Calls For U.N. Secretary General Guterres to Resign
item.description: Israel called for the U.N. secretary general to resign after he said that Hamas’s “appalling attacks cannot justify the collective punishment of the Palestinian people.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Seth Wenig/Associated Press
item.media:description: The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, right, talking with two U.S. officials: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and the U.N. ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, before a Security Council meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Says a Cease-Fire in the Israel War Would Only Benefit Hamas
item.description: A White House spokesman said the administration supported humanitarian pauses to allow aid to reach Gaza and civilians to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States has not discussed any red lines with Israel, said John F. Kirby, a White House spokesman.

item.title: After Outcry, Writers Guild Tries to Explain Silence on Hamas Attack
item.description: The union said it had made no public statement because “we are American labor leaders, aware of our limitations and humbled by the magnitude of this conflict.”
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 300 screenwriters signed an open letter to the Writers Guild of America asking why it had not publicly denounced the Oct. 7 attack.

item.title: Polish Bishop Resigns After Reports of Priest Holding Orgy
item.description: A priest in the bishop’s diocese was accused of holding a sex party in his church apartment that involved a male prostitute who lost consciousness.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: Families of Hostages Kidnapped By Hamas Rally to Put Pressure on the U.N.
item.description: Relatives of those being held in Gaza rallied outside U.N. headquarters on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ronen Neutra, right, spoke at a rally outside the United Nations headquarters in New York on Tuesday. Mr. Neutra’s son, Omer, has been held by Hamas in Gaza since the group’s terrorist attacks on Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: Yocheved Lifshitz, Israeli Hostage Freed by Hamas, Details Captivity in Gaza
item.description: Yocheved Lifshitz, a grandmother and Israeli peace activist, was kidnapped, beaten and held in tunnels built by Hamas for 17 days.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Alexi J. Rosenfeld/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ms. Lifshitz said her captors provided the hostages with food and medicine.

item.title: Ukrainian ‘Artifacts’ Seized in Spain May Not Be Treasures, Experts Say
item.description: The Spanish police seized gold pieces believed to be Greco-Scythian artifacts, dating back centuries, and arrested the people selling them. But archaeologists are not so sure of their value.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The National Police in Spain said its officers had seized 11 pieces of gold stolen from Ukraine. They are believed to date as far back as the 4th and 8th centuries B.C., but experts are doubtful of their authenticity.

item.title: What to Know About Dengue Fever as Cases Spread to New Places
item.description: Dengue, the excruciating mosquito-borne disease, is surging throughout the world and coming to places that had never had it. California just confirmed a rare U.S. case.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jaime Saldarriaga/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Aedes aegypti mosquito, which has been driving many of the current outbreaks, is native to Africa. But decades ago it spread to the rest of the world via trade routes and adapted to thrive in urban areas.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Gaza Death Toll Climbs
item.description: Plus remembering Park Seo-Bo and his art.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourning their relatives during their funeral in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Tuesday.

item.title: State Dinner to Bring Together Biden, Australia’s Leader and the B-52s
item.description: President Biden will welcome Anthony Albanese, the prime minister of Australia, for meetings and a state dinner in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The state visit will give President Biden an opportunity to nurture relations with an ally he sees as key to countering China.

item.title: Israel Barrages Gaza With Airstrikes
item.description: Israel said it struck more than 400 targets in Gaza in its broadest single-day assault of the conflict. Palestinian officials said more than 700 were killed, the highest one-day toll of the war.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning relatives killed in an airstrike on Tuesday in Khan Younis, in the Gaza Strip, after an Israeli aerial bombardment that Israel said was the heaviest of the war, and that Gazan officials said was the deadliest.

item.title: 85-Year Old Israeli Hostage Held in Gaza Says She ‘Went Through Hell’
item.description: Yocheved Lifshitz offered the first public account to emerge from the more than 200 hostages estimated to be held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Erik Marmor/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yocheved Lifshitz, 85, spoke to members of the news media on Tuesday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Amid Intense Fighting, Ukraine Orders Evacuation of Children
item.description: The evacuations from villages near the front line underscored the ferocity of the fighting as both Ukraine and Russia press bloody assaults.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter waiting to be evacuated from Kupiansk Vuzlova, eastern Ukraine, last month. Evacuations often coincide with periods of particularly fierce fighting.

item.title: Israel Prepares to Enter ‘Devil’s Playground’ of City Combat in Gaza
item.description: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in the Nuseirat market in central Gaza on Monday.

item.title: At Least One Dead, Others Missing After Ships Collide in North Sea
item.description: Two cargo vessels collided in a busy shipping lane. At least one mariner is dead and several others are missing.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Dietmar Hasenpusch/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The 299-foot British cargo vessel Verity off Kiel, Germany, in 2014.

item.title: Macron Suggests an International Coalition to Fight Hamas During Israel Visit
item.description: The French president also suggested that the international coalition once deployed to fight the Islamic State could also fight Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Ena
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, left, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Several People Hospitalized in Austria After Taking Suspected Fake Ozempic
item.description: The drug, used to treat diabetes, has become popular as a weight loss treatment. Now, officials are warning of counterfeit versions circulating in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (Great Britain)
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger/Reuters

item.title: China Dismisses Gen. Li Shangfu, Its Defense Minister, Amid Speculation
item.description: The unexplained dismissal of Gen. Li Shangfu, the military’s top diplomat, came shortly after the foreign minister and two top commanders in the country’s rocket forces were also ousted.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: How Hwee Young/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Chinese State Councilor and Minister of National Defence General Li Shangfu during a welcoming ceremony at a forum for regional officials in Singapore, in June.

item.title: Israel Says It Will Destroy Hamas. But Who Will Govern Gaza?
item.description: Israel has set itself a stiff challenge in aiming to vanquish Hamas. But an even bigger question looms: Once in Gaza, how and when does Israel get out?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers taking part in an artillery drill in southern Israel on Monday.

item.title: Washington State Senator Arrested at Hong Kong Airport on Gun Charge
item.description: A Washington state senator, Jeff Wilson, said he discovered the pistol on his flight and notified customs officials at the Hong Kong airport.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at the Hong Kong International Airport, where a Washington State senator was arrested on Friday night.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Israel ramps up Gaza strikes.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women mourning over the loss of those killed in the Israeli raids on of Deir al-Balah city from inside Shohadaa Al-Aqsa Hospital in the central Gaza Strip on Monday.

item.title: Jamaica Fears Brain Drain as Teachers Leave for U.S. Schools
item.description: Severe teacher shortages in the United States are prompting schools to recruit foreign teachers, sparking fears that education in Jamaica will suffer.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times

item.title: I.E.A. Sees Oil, Gas and Coal Demand Peaking By 2030
item.description: The prediction, which has stirred controversy among oil producers, is a sign of a sweeping transformation in the global energy landscape.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Naughton coal power plant in Kemmerer, Wyo., is slated to be decommissioned by 2025.

item.title: 13 Law Enforcement Officers Killed in Ambush in Mexico
item.description: The attack was in the Mexican state of Guerrero, which has been plagued by turf wars between drug cartels.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Francisco Robles/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Security officials recovering evidence at the site where 13 security officials were killed in an ambush by unidentified assailants in Coyuca de Benítez, in the state of Guerrero, Mexico, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Intensifies Strikes on Gaza as Its Allies Call for More Palestinian Aid
item.description: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed building in central Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Gaza Invasion Delays Raise Questions in Israel
item.description: So pervasive is the pall of chaos in Israel’s government that top officials saw fit to assure a traumatized public that they are “working in close and full cooperation, around the clock.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers cleaning the barrel of a tank on Saturday.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Former Leader, Gets Driver’s License at 53
item.description: The former first minister, who resigned and quit as leader of the Scottish National Party before her arrest in June, said seeking a driver’s license at 53 had taken her out of her comfort zone.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, the former first minister of Scotland, said on Monday that she had passed her driving test for the first time.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes
item.description: Plus the worldwide popularity of Lionel Messi’s pink jersey.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians carried children and their father from the Al-Zinati family, who were killed during Israeli air strikes in Khan Yunis in the southern Gaza Strip on Monday.

item.title: Train Collision in Bangladesh Leaves at Least 17 Dead
item.description: The accident, between a passenger train and a freight train, also injured over 100 people.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The site of a train collision in Bhairab, about 50 miles east of Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Shows Raw Footage From Hamas Attacks on Oct. 7
item.description: The Israeli military showed the compilation to foreign reporters on a day when Israel continued to bombard Gaza with heavy airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photos of Israeli citizens who are being held hostage in Gaza are displayed in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From Argentina’s Election
item.description: Javier Milei, a libertarian economist often compared to Donald Trump, will face off against Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, in a runoff next month.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Natalie Alcoba
item.media:credit: Tomas Cuesta/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Voters will decide between Sergio Massa, left, and Javier Milei in a runoff election next month.

item.title: Germany’s Far-Left Wagenknecht Forms New Populist Party
item.description: Sahra Wagenknecht has announced a new party, which could become another populist force scrambling German politics.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Annegret Hilse/Reuters
item.media:description: The leftist politician Sahra Wagenknecht has announced that she will form her own party.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas War Imperils Action Against Global Warming
item.description: Oil prices could surge. Disagreements between nations could worsen. The conflict complicates already fragile global diplomacy ahead of crucial climate talks.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the country’s south on Saturday. If war spreads it could hinder global cooperation on climate.
